texts.shortText: Previously incorrectly thought to be Actinia equina (a valid but European species); at one point also invalidly named A. mandelae.

Column short, squat and smooth, glossy dark red, tentacles about 90 in number, relatively short and lighter red to brown than column. A characteristic row of round, bright blue spherules found underneath the outer ring of tentacles.

Also readily recognized by its habitat, as it is one of very few anemones found high in the intertidal and able to survive in air for extended periods.
Column diameter usually about 20 mm. When open can reach 60 mm across, including tentacles.

Global: Currently recorded as endemic to South Africa, although samples reported under the name E. equina from West Africa may turn out to represent this, rather than the European, species.

Local/Regional: Port Nolloth to about East London. A green form also found around Durban.

Easily recognized by virtue of both its appearance (uniform glossy dark-red colour and blue spherule) and its unusual habitats, being the only regional anemone to survive out of water for extended periods.

 Usually occurs singly or in small spread-out groups in shaded gullies or rocky overhangs in the mid- to low- intertidal. When exposed to air closes up tightly, trapping water in the body cavity and hanging like plump, ripe fruit from the rock surface. Water is gradually released from the mouth to keep the animal moist and to reduce body temperature via evaporative cooling.

South African specimens were originally thought to represent the widespread European species A. equina and were only recognized and described as a local endemic species in 2011.

The prey spectrum of this species differs from that of most other regional intertidal anemones and it is the only species to feature insects as a significant component of the diet. The most common group found in the guts of specimens from the Cape Peninsula were small bivalves (28%), particularly the tiny Nucula nucleus; followed by insects (26%) and then isopods (24%).

Members of this genus are unusual in that larvae are brooded within the gut cavity and released as tiny, fully-formed tiny anemones 1–3 mm in diameter. These settle on adjacent rocks close to the adults (see photo below). Single adults of the European species have been recorded brooding up to 100 embryos.

Unlikely to be confused with any other regional anemones due to the uniform dark rusty-red colour, row of blue spherules outside the tentacles and ability to survive in air. Similar in colour to the Natal anemone Anemonia natalensis, which is common in KwaZulu-Natal, but that species normally occurs in rock pools and has radiating lines across the oral disc from the mouth to the bases of the tentacles.

Kruger, LM & Griffiths, CL (1996). Sources of nutrition in sea anemones from the Western Cape, South Africa. South African Journal of Zoology, 31, 110–119.

Laird, MC (2013). Taxonomy, systematics and biodiversity of South African Actiniaria and Corallimorpharia. PhD Thesis, Department of Zoology, University of Cape Town.

Schama, R, Mitchell, M, & Solé-Cava, AM (2012). Actinia ebhayiensis sp. nov., a new species of sea anemone (Anthozoa: Actiniaria: Actiniidae) from South Africa. Journal of the Marine Biological Association of the United Kingdom, 92(5), 885–894.
